snippet: A married team of scientists, their mentor and a rotating cadre of graduate students have been observing disturbing declines in wildlife on the tiny island of Tatoosh in Washington State.
abstract: Scientists conducting research on Tatoosh Island, Wash, say they are seeing disturbing declines in wildlife that could prove a bellwether for oceanic change globally; historically hardy murre and gull populations are now only half what they were a decade ago; shifts are related to huge declines in the water's pH level, attributed to absorption of excess carbon dioxide released by burning of fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: A married team of scientists, their mentor and a rotating cadre of graduate students have been observing disturbing declines in wildlife on the tiny island of Tatoosh in Washington State.

headline.seo: Scientists in Washington State Adopt Tiny Island as Climate-Change Bellwether
headline.main: Scientists Adopt Tiny Island as a Warming Bellwether
headline.print_headline: Scientists Adopt Tiny Island As a Warming Bellwether
